intro: Abutilon calderonii, commonly known as the Mexican velvetleaf, is a shrub native to Mexico and Central America. It is characterized by its fuzzy, velvety leaves that give it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom in clusters, typically during the spring and summer months. Its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release small, round seeds. Abutilon calderonii is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of environmental conditions.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon calderonii is primarily native to Mexico. It is found in the states of Oaxaca and Chiapas. This plant grows in tropical and subtropical regions, often in humid environments. It thrives in areas with well-drained soils and partial to full sunlight. Abutilon calderonii is commonly found in forests and along stream banks in its native range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon calderonii was mainly introduced to areas with warm, humid climates where it can thrive in well-drained soils. It is commonly found in regions with mild winters and long growing seasons, such as parts of Central and South America. This plant is often cultivated for its ornamental value due to its attractive foliage and showy flowers. It has been introduced to various tropical and subtropical regions as a decorative plant. However, in some areas, it has become invasive, outcompeting native species and altering local ecosystems.
